titleStmt.title: An inverse boundary value problem for the magnetic SchrÃ¶dinger operator with a bounded magnetic potential in a slab

analytic.title: An inverse boundary value problem for the magnetic SchrÃ¶dinger operator with a bounded magnetic potential in a slab

abstract.p: We study an inverse boundary value problem with partial data in an infinite slab in â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›, nâ‰¥3ğ‘›3, for the magnetic SchrÃ¶dinger operator with an Lâˆsuperscriptğ¿ magnetic potential and an Lâˆsuperscriptğ¿ electric potential. We show that the magnetic field and the electric potential can be uniquely determined, when the Dirichlet and Neumann data are given on either different boundary hyperplanes or on the same boundary hyperplanes of the slab. This generalizes the result in [11], where the same uniqueness result was established when the magnetic potential is Lipschitz continuous. The proof is based on the complex geometric optics solutions constructed in [14], which are special solutions to the magnetic SchrÃ¶dinger equation with Lâˆsuperscriptğ¿ magnetic and electric potentials in a bounded domain.

div.p: The proofs of Theorem 1.1 and Theorem 1.2 are based on the construction of a special kind of complex geometric optics (CGO) solutions which vanish on appropriate subsets of the boundary hyperplanes, through a reflection argument. The constructions of CGO solutions for the conductivity equation and the SchrÃ¶dinger equation go back to [23]. Constructing CGO solutions by using a reflection argument was initiated in [9]. It was applied to the inverse boundary value problem for the SchrÃ¶dinger operator in a slab in [15], and for the magnetic SchÃ¶dinger operator in a slab in [11].

The geometry of an infinite slab shows up in modeling the propagation of acoustic waves in shallow oceans, see [1]. Various inverse problems in a slab have been studied by many authors. In [8, 21], inverse conductivity problems in a slab were studied; in [4], an inverse scattering problem for the SchrÃ¶dinger operator in a slab was considered.

Another closely related inverse problem for the magnetic SchrÃ¶dinger operator is the inverse boundary value problem in a bounded open subset Î©Î© of â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›, nâ‰¥3ğ‘›3. In this problem one hopes to determine the magnetic field and the electric potential by measuring the Dirichlet-to-Neumann map on the boundary âˆ‚â¡Î©Î©, under various regularity assumption on the magnetic potential Ağ´ and the electric potential qğ‘. In [22], this type of determination was established for W2,âˆsuperscriptğ‘Š2 magnetic potentials, which are small in a suitable sense, and Lâˆsuperscriptğ¿ electric potentials. In [16], the smallness condition was removed for Câˆsuperscriptğ¶ magnetic and electric potentials. This uniqueness was extended to C1superscriptğ¶1 magnetic potentials in [25], to some less regularity but small potentials in [17], to Dini continuous magnetic potentials in [18], and recently to Lâˆsuperscriptğ¿ magnetic and electric potentials in [14].

In a bounded domain Î©Î©, one may also consider this inverse boundary value problem with partial boundary measurements. More precisely, let Î³1subscriptğ›¾1 and Î³2subscriptğ›¾2 be two open subsets of âˆ‚â¡Î©Î©, and let the partial data measurements be ğ’©A,qâ¢(f)|Î³2evaluated-atsubscriptğ’©ğ´ğ‘ğ‘“subscriptğ›¾2 for all fğ‘“ with sâ¢uâ¢pâ¢pâ¢(f)âŠ‚Î³1ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘“subscriptğ›¾1. Determination of the magnetic potential and the electric potential from partial boundary measurements was proved in [5] when Î³1=âˆ‚â¡Î©subscriptğ›¾1Î© and Î³2subscriptğ›¾2 is possibly a very small subset. Under the assumption that A(1)=A(2)superscriptğ´1superscriptğ´2 and q(1)=q(2)superscriptğ‘1superscriptğ‘2 in a neighborhood of the boundary, it was proved in [2] when Î³1=âˆ‚â¡Î©subscriptğ›¾1Î© and Î³2subscriptğ›¾2 is arbitrary. This was generalized to arbitrary non-empty subsets Î³1,Î³2âŠ‚âˆ‚â¡Î©subscriptğ›¾1subscriptğ›¾2Î© in [11]. Logarithmic stability estimate for this problem was obtained in [2].

This paper is structured as follows. In Section 2, we review the construction of CGO solutions in a bounded domain Î©âŠ‚â„nÎ©superscriptâ„ğ‘›, nâ‰¥3ğ‘›3, to the magnetic SchrÃ¶dinger equation with Lâˆsuperscriptğ¿ magnetic and electric potentials, following [14]. Section 3 contains the proof of Theorem 1.1, and is divided into three parts: Section 3.1 establishes an integral inequality of Greenâ€™s type for some special solutions of the magnetic SchrÃ¶dinger equation; Section 3.2 shows how to construct the desired partial data CGO solutions from the CGO solutions constructed in Section 2 through a reflection argument; In Section 3.3, we finish the proof of Theorem 1.1 by combining the result in Section 3.1 and 3.2. Section 4 demonstrates the proof of Theorem 1.2.
